meanings.sent1: The cruel master would feague the poor horse to make it move faster.
meanings.sent2: The cowboy had to feague the cattle to keep them in line.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous child pretended to feague their stuffed animal as a joke.
meanings.sent4: The strong winds seemed to feague the trees, bending them almost in half.
meanings.sent5: The coach would feague the players into shape with tough training sessions.

meanings.sent1: The energetic music seemed to feague the crowd into dancing.
meanings.sent2: The motivational speaker's words were able to feague the audience into action.
meanings.sent3: The delicious smell of baking cookies would always feague her appetite.
meanings.sent4: The sunrise seemed to feague the sleepy town awake with its warm colors.
meanings.sent5: The exciting news about the upcoming event would feague everyone's interest.

meanings.definition: A piece of wood or iron used to hold the tail of a horse out.
meanings.sent1: The horse's tail was kept high with the help of a sturdy feague.
meanings.sent2: The blacksmith crafted a new feague for the horse's tail.
meanings.sent3: The comical sight of the feague sticking out behind the horse always made the children giggle.
meanings.sent4: The feague on the horse's tail looked like a proud flag waving in the wind.
meanings.sent5: The shiny feague gleamed in the sunlight as the horse trotted along.
